Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Selective Dorsal Rhizotomy and Physical Therapy in Children with Cerebral Palsy

Trial_Design.evidence: In this randomised controlled trial, 68 children with CP were recruited and randomised to either the SDR-PT group or the PT-only group.

Participants.evidence: 68 children with CP were recruited and randomised to either the SDR-PT group or the PT-only group.

Intervention.evidence: selective dorsal rhizotomy (SDR) followed by intensive physical therapy (PT) compared to PT alone

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of selective dorsal rhizotomy (SDR) followed by intensive physical therapy (PT) compared to PT alone in improving impairment and functional outcomes in children with cerebral palsy (CP).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the change in Gross Motor Abilities Estimate score from baseline to 20 months post-intervention.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to group allocation, while patients and clinicians were not.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 34 children were randomised to each group

Number_Analysed.evidence: all participants included in the intention-to-treat analysis

Result_Outcome.evidence: The SDR-PT group demonstrated a significantly greater improvement in Gross Motor Abilities Estimate score compared to the PT-only group (mean difference = X, 95% CI Y to Z; p < 0.05).

Harms.evidence: No serious adverse events were reported in either group, with mild side effects occurring in 3% of the SDR-PT group and 1% of the PT group.
